In HVAC control problems, model-based optimal control methods have been extensively studied and verified by many researchers, but they highly depend on the accuracy of the model, a large amount of historical data, and the deployment of different sensors. With respect to the above problems, this paper proposed a Multi-Agent deep reinforcement learning method for the building Cooling Water System Control (MA-CWSC) to optimize the load distribution, cooling tower fan frequency, and cooling water pump frequency of different types of chillers, which provide a model-free and online learning mechanism. In the learning process, unlike the traditional reinforcement learning methods, the proposed control method uses five agents to control different controllable parts by parallel learning, which can greatly reduce the action space and speed up the convergence rate. In order to verify the effectiveness of the propose-d control method, based on the actual building cooling water system parameters and related historical data, we construct an experimental building cooling water system model, and moreover, we test the MA-CWSC method, model-based control method (optimal control method), baseline method, and single-agent deep reinforcement learning (deep Q-network). The experimental results show that the energy saving performance of the proposed MA-CWSC method is significantly better than the rule-based control method (11.1% improvement), and is very close to that of the model-based control method (only 0.5% difference). In addition, the MA-CWSC method has a faster learning rate compared to the deep Q-network (DQN) control method. Keywords Multi-agent deep reinforcement learning Model-free control Building cooling water system Building energy efficiency HVAC control 1 1.Introduction According to statistics, for the total energy consumption of buildings, HVAC system energy consumption accounts for as much as or even more than 50% [1]. For the HVAC system, the energy consumption of chillers is an important part of HVAC energy consumption [2]. Therefore, the optimization of chillers control is particularly important to reduce the energy consumption of the entire HVAC system or even the total energy consumption of buildings. At present, optimizing different chiller loading (Optimal Chiller Loading, OCL) is one of the main methods for the optimal control of chillers [3]. This method mainly optimizes the total system load distribution mode to make the partial load ratio (PLR) of different chillers more reasonable for achieving energy saving. In addition, the cooling water system is also essential for HVAC, mainly including cooling towers, cooling water pumps, and so on, which aim to discharge the heat rejected by the chillers [4]. Meanwhile, the optimization operation of the cooling water system also has a great impact on the Coefficient of Performance (COP) of the chiller [3]. Therefore, both the chiller and the cooling water circulation system need to be considered while realizing the optimization control for the HVAC system. In optimal control problems for HVAC systems, optimal control methods mainly include rule-based control, model-based control, model-free control, and so on. Rule-based control methods tend to be static, and control rules are based on the engineer’s experience. Aaron Tam developed and evaluated a rule-based control policy for residential ice storage systems [5]. Hu Jingfan adopted a rules-based control method to optimize HVAC operation and conserve operation costs [6]. Rule-based control methods usually have a poor energy conservation effect and are not updated as equipment ages. Usually, the model-based control method requires a large amount of data and sensors to establish an accurate HVAC model. Huang Sen [7] established a simulation model for the HVAC system containing multiple coolers, cooling towers, and constant speed cooling water pumps. Yao et al. adapted the state-space method to enhance the system COP, which establishes the model of the HVAC system and refrigeration system [8]. However, model-based control methods usually lack robustness and are not suitable for old buildings that lack historical data and sensors. Moreover, due to the aging of the equipment and other factors, the model needs to be updated regularly for model optimization, which requires maintenance personnel to have high-level technical skills. In order to avoid establishing accurate HVAC models, some researchers focus on model-free control methods. Due to the increasing popularity of Machine Learning methods, we aim to devise a good management strategy using data instead of complex mathematical models. Reinforcement Learning (RL) controllers have started being increasingly assessed in HVAC management systems [9,10]. Sajjad Baghaee et al. [11] used Q-learning to simultaneously regulate indoor CO2 concentration and the HVAC system. Samy Faddel et al. [12] proposed a data-driven Q-learning method to minimize building energy consumption while ensuring the comfort of indoor personnel. Qiu et al. [13] proposed to optimize the cooling water pump frequency and cooling tower fan frequency with Q-learning, where the system cooling load and outdoor wet-bulb temperature are taken as states of reinforcement learning. However, this method did not take the influence of the system load distribution into account on energy-conserving performance. In HVAC control, traditional RL-based control methods, such as Q-learning and SARSA (State, Action, Reward, next State, next Action), usually only solve the problem of small state space and action space [14]. In recent work, the DQN control method, which combines Q-learning with deep neural networks, has solved this problem very well [15]. Mnih et al. [16] proposed the Deep Q-network (DQN), which combined deep neural network and Q-learning method to achieve function approximation of high-dimensional state space and realize end-to-end decision control. Experiments have proved that in Atari game control, it can be able to obtain a decision-making capability close to or even surpassing human experts. And in HVAC control problems, Ki Uhn Ahn et al. [17] used EnergyPlus to construct the HVAC system and used DQN to optimize the control of chilled water temperature, cooling water temperature, and Air Handling Unit (AHU) open rate. After 15 days of training, the experiments show that DQN can reduce 15.7% of energy consumption (compared to the Baseline method). However, it does not take into consideration the problem of slower algorithm convergence caused by the large action space, the impact of cooling water pumps, cooling tower fan frequency, and load distribution of different types of chillers in HVAC systems. Most HVAC model-free control methods based on deep reinforcement learning use an agent to optimize control of multiple system setpoints, resulting in a larger action space and a longer training period. Srinarayana Nagarathinam et al. [18] proposed a multi-agent reinforcement learning based control (MARCO) method that uses independent agents to optimize control of AHUs and chillers, and utilize transfer learning methods between subsystems to accelerate agent learning. The results show that MARCO has advantages in multi-variable optimization. But the method does not take the impact of the frequency of cooling towers and cooling water pumps into account on the energy consumption of HVAC systems. Liang Yu [19] used a multi-agent reinforcement learning algorithm to optimize the valve position and air supply rate to maintain indoor thermal comfort and air quality comfort while minimizing HVAC energy consumption, where only two optimization variables (damper valve position and air supply rate) are considered. Marco Biemann et al. [20] compared four model-free actor-critic reinforcement learning algorithms in a data-center simulation. Yan Du et al. [21] proved the economy and time efficiency of the DDPG (Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient) method in multi-zone residential. Currently, reinforcement learning (RL) has two major advantages in HVAC. First, the RL-based control method does not need the specific model of the equipment, but only the nameplate information of some equipment. Second, compared with other control methods, the RL-based control method is finally implemented a simple state-feedback control at each time step. However, most RL-based control methods are trained offline and then deployed, which leads to a large amount of data that should be prepared in the early stage of deployment. As discussed above, rule-based control methods typically have poor energy savings and require experience to set the rules. The biggest drawback of model-based control methods is that they are highly dependent on accurate system models and many sensors, which is difficult to provide for some buildings. Another drawback is the higher maintenance cost in the real world. Due to the aging of the equipment and other factors, the model needs to be updated regularly for model optimization, which requires maintenance personnel to have high-level technical skills. Thus, more and more researchers try to use model-free RL methods to solve HVAC control problems such as Q-learning or DQN, both of which commonly used in this problem. However, they often suffer from the slow convergence due to the large action space. In this paper, to solve the problem that the DQN control method has a slow convergence rate in the building cooling water system, we adopted the multi-agent RL methods and allocate the original action space to multiple agents in order to accelerate the convergence rate by the parallel learning. It is important to note that the proposed method is trained online and requires only a small amount of weather data early in deployment. And during the operation, the control method will make full use of the data collected from related equipment. The following is a summary of the main contributions of this paper: • We proposed a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning algorithm for the building cooling water system control to optimize cooling towers, cooling water pumps, and chillers in the building cooling water system. There are four advantages in this method. Firstly, to enhance the practical application of the method, we considered time-varying set points for cooling towers, cooling pumps, and chillers that are more in line with the actual situation. Secondly, to solve the problem of slow convergence of traditional model-free methods (or even unable to converge because of the large state or action space), we consider a multi-agent scenario where each agent controls each sub-equipment of the building cooling water system separately. Thirdly, to solve the problem of traditional control methods requiring equipment model parameters and historical data, the proposed method is model-free and does not require any prior knowledge of uncertain parameters. Finally, due to the equipment aging, the model (model-based) needs to be updated continuously to maintain the accuracy of the model, which has a high maintenance cost, while the proposed method is maintenance free. • We developed a simulation platform based on Python for the validation of the proposed MA-CWSC method. We consider a building with three cooling towers, three cooling pumps, and three chillers (different types of chillers), using real weather and cooling loads as inputs, and evaluating the energy consumption used. • We compared MA-CWSC with various control methods, including the rule-based control method, model-based control method, and the DQN control method. The experimental results show that the energy saving performance of the proposed MA-CWSC method is significantly better than the rule-based control method (baseline control method), and is very close to that of the model-based control method (the method of exhaustion). In addition, the MA-CWSC method has a faster learning rate compared to the DQN control method. 2 2.Related theories 2.1 Markov decision process Reinforcement learning problems can usually be modeled as a Markov decision process (MDP), represented by a quadruple: M = < S , A , R , P > [22]. (a) S represents the state space. (b) A represents the action space. (c) R represents the immediate reward received after transitioning from state s T to state s T + 1 (d) P represents the probability that action a in state s T will lead to state s T + 1 . For an MDP problem, at each time step t, the agent takes an action a T according to the state s T and obtains an immediate reward r T , and then obtains the next state s T+1 , as is shown in Fig. 1 . A policy function π is a probability of choosing an action a in the state s . Therefore, the goal in a MDP is to find an optimal policy. In reinforcement learning, the value function is used to find an optimal policy. The value function includes state-value function V π and action-value function Q π . Q π ( s , a ) represents expected return starting from s , taking the action a , and thereafter following policy π . The action-value function is usually used to evaluate the policy π : (1) Q π s , a = r s , a + γ ∑ s ′ ∈ S p s ′ | s , a ∑ a ′ ∈ A π s ′ , a ′ Q π s ′ , a ′ Where r s , a represents the immediate reward received by choosing action a in the state s , γ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) is the discount factor, and p ( s ′ | s , a ) represents the probability that action a in state s will lead to state s ′ . Eq. (1) is also called Bellman Equation. The goal of reinforcement learning is to obtain the optimal policy, and the Q ∗ ( s , a ) can be expressed as: (2) Q ∗ s , a = r s , a + γ ∑ s ′ ∈ S p s ′ | s , a max a ′ ∈ A Q ∗ s ′ , a ′ Eq. (2) is also called the optimal Bellman Equation. 2.2 Deep Q-Network The DQN is a combination of Q-learning and a deep neural network (DNN). In the DQN, the input is the current state, and the output is the Q value for each action at the current state [16]. Unlike the supervised learning algorithm, there are no labeled samples for the DNN to learn in deep reinforcement learning. To handle this issue, two DNNs are designed for the DQN algorithm: one is called the target network, and the other is called the behavior network. Both networks are initialized with the same parameters and the same structure. As the training proceeds, the behavior network is updated at a faster speed than the target network. The loss function in the DQN is defined as the mean square error (MSE) between the target Q value and the behavior Q value as shown in Eq. (3). Once the loss function is calculated, the parameters of the behavior network will be updated based on its gradient to the loss function. The algorithm will continue updating until the output from the target network and the behavior network are close to each other. (3) L β = E r + γ max a ′ Q s ′ , a ′ | β - Q s , a | β 2 2.3 Multi-Agent deep reinforcement learning algorithm Compared with single-agent deep reinforcement learning, multi-agent deep reinforcement learning involves multiple agents interacting with the environment, and the combined actions of multiple agents jointly affect the environment. Therefore, the Markov Decision Process (MDP) is summarized as Stochastic Game [23] (SG). The five-tuple of the definition of SG: < M , S , { A i } i ∈ M , P r , { r i } i ∈ M > , where M represents the agent's quantity, S represents the set of states, { A i } is the action of the i t h agent, Pr is the random state transition function, and r i is the reward that the i t h agent gets in each round. The joint action set of all agents is defined as: A = { A 1 , A 2 ⋯ A M } , the joint action determines the value function of each agent: Q π : S × A → R M . Multi-agent deep reinforcement learning algorithms can be classified into Fully Cooperative, Fully Competitive, and Mixed and it depends on their reward functions [24]. In the fully cooperative algorithm, the reward function of agents is the same, indicating that all agents have a common goal. Representative algorithms include Team Q-learning, Distributed Q-learning, and so on. In the fully competitive algorithm, the reward function of agents is the opposite. The agent's goal is to maximize its own reward and minimize others' reward. The representative algorithm is Minimax-Q. In the fully Mixed algorithm, the reward function of agents needs to achieve a balanced effect. In this paper, each piece of equipment (cooling water pumps, cooling towers, and chillers) is optimized by a corresponding agent. Because the optimization goals of all agents are the same, the fully cooperative algorithm is adopted. Under the cooperation mechanism, each agent shares the same reward, that is, r 1 = r 2 = ⋯ = r M , as shown in Fig. 2 . 3 Case system 3.1 Workflow of the system In order to protect these chillers and reduce unnecessary refrigerating capacity, the system uses a sequence control method [25] to determine the turn-on and turn-off of each chiller. Therefore, the main process of system operation consists of two parts: the sequential control of chillers and the optimal control based on MA-CWSC. As shown in Fig. 3 , the flow of the proposed control method can be represented by the following steps. A) The turn-on and turn-off of all chillers. At each time step t, according to the cooling load, the system will decide to turn on or turn off related chillers firstly, as shown on the right side of Fig. 3. 1) If the cooling load is less than 40% of the rated refrigerating capacity of one small chiller, all chillers need to be turned off; (To protect chillers, the entire central chiller plant remains turned off if the cooling load is below 40% of the nominal cooling capacity of the chiller. [26]) 2) If the cooling load is between 40% of the rated refrigerating capacity of one small chiller and the rated refrigerating capacity of one big chiller, only one small chiller needs to be turned on; 3) If the cooling load is between the rated refrigerating capacity of one big chiller and a small chiller, only one big chiller needs to be turned on; 4) If the cooling load is between the rated refrigerating capacity of one big chiller and the total rated refrigerating capacity of one big chiller and one small chiller, one big chiller and one small chiller need to be turned on; 5) If the cooling load is between the rated refrigerating capacity of two big chillers and the total rated refrigerating capacity of one big chiller and one small chiller, two big chillers need to be turned on; 6) Otherwise, all chillers need to be turned on. B) Observe the state s t . The state s t is constructed by the real-time data, including cooling load and outdoor wet-bulb temperature. C) Distribute cooling load. In order to ensure that the PLR of each chiller is between [0.4, 1] [27], according to the cooling load, a reasonable ratio considered as an action in RL can be chosen by ε - g r e e d y policy based on Q values. D) Choose the frequency of cooling towers and cooling water pumps. The frequency of cooling water pump f pump and cooling tower f tower are chosen by ε - g r e e d y policy, which is to make the best choice for the current state. The system COP can be calculated under the current action a t ( ratio , f pump , f tower ), which is also considered as the reward in MA-CWSC. E) Train an MA-CWSC agent. Sample data are stored in the format ( s t , a t , r t , s t + 1 ) to construct the replay buffer. In the learning process, batch samples can be randomly selected from the replay buffer to train the MA-CWSC agent. F) End the current learning and move to the step (A). 3.2 Characteristics and constraints of the model 3.2.1 Objective of optimization System coefficient of performance diametrically reflects the energy saving performance of the HVAC system [28]. Consequently, the objective of the optimization is to measure the COP. The system COP and system cooling load can be calculated by Eq. (4) and Eq. (5) respectively. (4) COP = CL s ∑ P chiller , i + P tower , i + P pump , i where P chiller , i is the power of the i th chiller (kW), P tower , i is the power of the i th cooling tower (kW), and P pump , i is the power of the i th cooling water pumps (kW). (5) C L s = C p × ρ × F chw × T chwr - T chws ÷ 3600 s / h 3.2.2 Preliminary knowledge and real-time data Before the learning process, the HVAC system is modeled as a MDP problem according to the system layout and nameplates of the equipment. Thereafter, real-time cooling load and outdoor wet-bulb temperature are provided to the MA-CWSC agent. Compared with model-based control methods and base-line control methods, model-free control methods do not require an accurate model of the HVAC system (such as the chiller system, the cooling tower system, the cooling water pump, and so on.). 3.2.3 Constraint condition The system contains 2 types of chillers (1 small chiller and 2 big chillers), 3 cooling towers, and 3 cooling water pumps, and each chiller is connected to a cooling water pump and a cooling tower. When the chiller is turned on, the connected cooling water pump and cooling tower are turned on. The specifications of all cooling towers and cooling pumps are the same, as listed in Table 1 . Moreover, here we present two assumptions: A) In this paper, we assume that chilled water pumps operate at rated power with constant chilled water flow. B) For different types of chillers, the cooling load distribution can be optimized. Although the cooling load distribution should also be optimized for the same type of chillers, Chang's [29] research results show that the optimal load distribution is just the same cooling load distribution, so for the same two big chillers, the load distribution could be treated as the same load distribution simply. That is, in this paper, we only need to do the load distribution between two types of chillers. In the system, because the distributed cooling load cannot be used to optimize the chiller control, it is usually converted into the chilled water outlet temperature to control the chiller, as shown in Eq. (6). (6) T chws , j , s e t = T chwr , j , r e f - C L j C p × ρ × F chw , j ÷ 3600 s / h where T chws , j , s e t is the outlet temperature of the chilled water of the j th chiller (°C), T chwr , j , r e f is the inlet temperature of chilled water of the j th chiller (°C), CL j is the cooling load assigned to the j th chiller ( kW ) and F chw , j is the chilled water flow of the j th chiller ( m 3 / h ), and. 4 MA-CWSC method This section presents all details of the proposed MA-CWSC method, including the formulation of the action, state, and reward. 4.1 MA-CWSC formulation According to MPD, it is intuitive that in the building cooling water system, the system cooling load can be formulated to the state; chilled Water outlet temperature setpoint, frequency of cooling pumps, and frequency of cooling towers can be formulated to the action; the COP of the system can be formulated to the reward (our goal is to maximize the COP of the current moment). 4.1.1 Action-space For an MDP, the executable control nodes are usually formulated as actions in RL. Therefore, the actions in this case system are the cooling load distribution, the frequency of cooling towers, and cooling water pumps. However, for DQN control, the combination of all the above factors will lead to a large action space, which greatly degrades the performance of the controller. In order to reduce the action space, multiple agents are used to control the cooling load distribution, the frequency of cooling towers, and cooling water pumps separately. In this way, for each agent, the action space is only the space of individual control nodes, rather than the space of all control nodes. In addition, the optimal control of the cooling water pump and cooling tower connected to the same type of the chiller should be the same. Then all actions of MA-CWSC at time step t are shown in Eqs. (7) to (9). (7) A tower = { a t 1 = f tower 1 , ⋯ , a t n chiller = f tower n chiller } (8) A pump = { a t n chiller + 1 = f pump n chiller + 1 , ⋯ , a t 2 n chiller = f pump 2 n chiller } (9) A ratio = { a t 2 n chiller + 1 = r a t i o 2 n chiller + 1 , ⋯ , a t 3 n chiller - 1 = r a t i o 3 n chiller - 1 } where a t k represents the action of the k th agent at time step t, n chiller represents the number of chiller types, f tower k represents the frequency of the cooling tower controlled by the k th agent, f pump k represents the frequency of the cooling water pump controlled by the k th agent, ratio k represents the ratio of cooling load controlled by the k th agent. n chiller determines the dimensions of ratio . In this case system, we consider the following two features: 1) The outdoor wet-bulb temperature ( T wet ), which has a relatively great impact on the heat dissipation performance of the case system; b) The system cooling load ( CL s ), which affects the load distribution. Therefore, the combination of C L s (kW) and T wet (°C) can be used as the state s t , as shown in Eq. (17). (17) s t = C L s t , T wet t 4.1.3 Reward For an MDP, goals that need to be optimized are usually formulated to the reward in RL. In this case system, we need to maximize the system COP, as shown in Eq.18. (18) r t + 1 = C O P = C L s ∑ P chiller k + P tower k + P pump k where P chiller k , P tower k and P pump k represents the power of the k th chiller, cooling tower, and cooling water pump, respectively. Q k s j , a j k ; θ k 2 with respect to the network parameter θ k 25: Every C step time-steps reset θ ^ k = θ k ,for each agent 26: end for 27: end for Algorithm 1 is a MA-CWSC method. The traditional DQN algorithm always overestimates the action value, which leads to slowing down the convergence of the value function. Compared with the DQN control method, the action space of each agent in the MA-CWSC method is reduced. Therefore, the MA-CWSC method is used to accelerate the convergence speed. The number of chiller types (n), the number of episodes ( EPISODES ), the total number of time-steps ( T ), in each EPISODE, minimum value of ε ( ε min ) and the decay value of ε ( Δ ε ) are parameters. R tower and R pump are taken as action-space of agents. Next, an independent reply memory, policy network, and target network are initialized for each agent. The training starts from line 4. For each episode, the environmental state is initialized as the initial state: s 0 . At the same time, ε linearly decays until it reaches the ε min . For each time step, the on–off signal of each chiller must be given firstly according to the system cooling load, which is distributed only when different types of chillers are turned on. Based on the PLR of each chiller, a reasonable ratio range R ratio will be calculated. MA-CWSC uses ε - g r e e d y to select an action. Then, based on the current state ( s t ), on–off signal, and the selected action ( a t ), the environment will move to the next state ( s t + 1 ) and calculate the reward ( r t + 1 ) as a response of the action taken at the previous control step. The quadruples ( s t , a t , r t + 1 , s t + 1 ) are stored in the reply memory of each agent, and the reply memory is constantly updated. To improve learning efficiency, the agent for ratio only stores quadruple when different types of chillers are turned on at the same time. For the k th agent, quadruples are randomly selected. Then, a mini-batch of quadruples is drawn randomly from the reply memory D k . y i k is calculated and parameter θ k are updated (lines 23–24). In line 25, the θ ^ k of Q ^ k will be updated in every C step time steps. 5 Construction of simulation environment This section focuses on the construction of the simulation platform, as an environment for the subsequent verification of various control methods. 5.1 Case study The HVAC system of a commercial office building in Shanghai is investigated. The types of equipment provided by the manufacturer are shown in Table 3 . The workflow of the system is shown in Fig. 3. The system layout is shown in Appendix B, and a simplified structure of the system is shown in Appendix C, where the cooling water system is a decoupled system. The colors in the figure represent the system cooling load, with dark colors representing a large amount of coiling load and light colors representing a little amount of coiling load(Based on maintaining 26 °C). T cws and T cwr are two coupled variables. T cws affects the output water temperature of the cooling tower, T cws and T cwr affects the performance of the chiller, and then affects T cws . Therefore, T cws and T cwr need to iterate through the loops of the three equipment models until they converged. The cut-off condition of convergence is that the error of T cwr does not exceed 0.1. If the value does not converge even after more than 50 loops, the last value is chosen as T cwr . T chws , T chwr , and F chw of the system are not iterated in the model. The simulation system consists of several cooling units, and there are many pipes mixing water. According to the convention, the water temperature at the main pipe is the weighted average of the water temperature in each branch pipe, and the weight is calculated according to the proportion of the water flow in each branch pipe. 7 Experimental results In this section, we compared MA-CWSC with three classical methods in the HVAC control problem, including the rule-based control method, model-based control method, and the DQN control method. And in order to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed MA-CWSC, we try to take the following three aspects: the convergence performance, the system operation performance, and the energy saving performance. 7.1 Experimental setup 7.1.1 MA-CWSC parameter setting Linear ε decay is used in the MA-CWSC method to improve the energy saving rate in the first year as much as possible and to guarantee a certain exploration rate to learn the global optimal solution when the equipment performance is aging. Δ ε is set to 0.0005 and ε min is set to 0.01. Each agent policy network and target network are composed of two hidden layers containing 30 neurons. Minibatch is set to 32. To increase the impact of the system COP at the current moment, we set γ = 0.01 . To improve the stability of the algorithm learning, we set C step = 200 and l e a r n i n g _ r a t e = 0.01 . Each agent has an input layer, an output layer, and a hidden layer. Each hidden layer has 32 nodes. The output layers of both the cooling water tower and the cooling tower agents have 26 nodes, while the output layer of the ratio agent has 10 nodes. as shown in Table 4 . We use Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) as the activation function for the hidden layers and the linear function for the output Q-value estimation. The weights and biases of the networks are initialized using Random-Uniform initialization. On average, it took about 3 h to be simulated on a machine with a 10th Generation Intel @ Core i5-10400F @ 4.3 GHz processor and 8 GB RAM. 7.1.2 Comparison method setting In the experiment, three control methods were compared with the MA-CWSC control method: baseline control method, DQN control method, and model-based control method. The baseline control method is designed to reflect the value of the proposed method. The model-based control method is designed to reflect the gap of performance between the proposed method and the best one. The DQN control method is designed to reflect the performance improvement of the proposed method with respect to the model-free control method. T chws , j , s e t is maintained between 5 °C and 9 °C to protect equipment and maintain indoor comfort. a) Baseline control method: The frequency of the cooling water pump and cooling tower fan are both set to 50 Hz to protect the chiller. At the same time, the T chws , j , s e t of each chiller is set to 6 °C (nominal value). b) DQN control method: The state is formulated to the combination of CL s and T wet : s t = C L s t , T wet t . The reward function is formulated to the system COP. When the big and small chillers are turned on at the same time, the frequency of all cooling tower fans and cooling water pumps remains the same which appropriately reduces the action space. All values in each setpoint space are arranged in the format of [ r a t i o , f tower , f pump ] to form action space(e.g. [ r a t i o = 0.9 , f tower = 50 , f pump = 50 ] , [ r a t i o = 0.9 , f tower = 50 , f pump = 49 ] , ⋯ ] ). c) Model-based control method: Use the OCL method based on constrained optimization and lagrange multiplier method to distribute system cooling load between big chillers and small chillers. The optimization goal of the OCL method is to minimize the power sum of all chillers (the left half of Eq. (22)). The right half of Eq. (22) is the constraint term. Eq. (23) represents the accurate model of the chiller (parameters in appendix E), where j represents the jth chiller. According to the real-time system cooling load and outdoor wet bulb temperature, the calculation method of traversal solution is used to find the optimal control action from the action space of the cooling tower and the cooling water pump. The curve is smoothed according to 5 independent repeated experiments. The equation used for processing is expressed by Eq. (26), where the weight is 0.999. The abscissa in the figure represents the number of training steps (each interval is 1 year), and the ordinate represents the averaged loss value. During the experiment, loss varies greatly in the first year and is more stable after the second year. Therefore, for the convenience of observation, (a) and (b) are the loss curves from the 1st to 20th year, and the loss curves from the 2nd to 20th year, respectively. Fig. 6(a) shows that the algorithm gradually converges from the 2nd year (Steps ≈ 4399), and Fig. 6(b) shows that the algorithm has converged in the 6th year (Steps≈21995). All the loss values converge to a stable minimum, which means that the control effect of all agents is stable relatively. (26) smoothe d loss t + 1 = w e i g h t × s m o o t h e d _ loss t + 1 - w e i g h t × loss t Fig. 7 shows trends in the cumulative reward of MA-CWSC and the DQN control method over 20 years, where round 1 to 5 are five independent repeated experiments. (The round 3 of the MA-CWSC is the best. The round 5 of the DQN is the best.) For MA-CWSC, the cumulative reward reaches a relatively large value in the first 6 years gradually and increases slowly after the 6th year. The DQN control method has a rapid increase in cumulative reward in the first 3 years, and then it is relatively stable. Until the 10th year later, it can get a larger cumulative reward. Compared with the DQN control method, each agent of MA-CWSC has a smaller action space, so it can learn a better policy much more quickly. This is also the main reason that MA-CWSC has performed better than the DQN control method in the first 10 years. Meanwhile, for MA-CWSC in this paper, each agent cannot access the information of other agents, so it is difficult to get the optimal policy overall, which is the main reason why the effect of MA-CWSC is slightly inferior to that of the DQN control method after the 15th year. 7.3 System operation analysis a) Chiller sequence control analysis. The sequence control of the system determines the turn on and off state of big and small chillers by analyzing real-time system cooling load, as shown in Fig. 4 Fig. 8 shows the sequence control results of the case system. The abscissa represents the number of days in 6 months, the ordinate represents the time in each day, and the color depth represents the turn on and off state of the chillers (0 means that all chillers are turned off, 1 means that only one small chiller is turned on, 2 means only one big chiller is turned on, 3 means that one big chiller and one small chiller are turned on at the same time, 4 means that two big chillers are turned on at the same time and 5 means that all chillers are turned on at the same time). The cooling load of the case system is relatively low in May, June, September, and October, and the cooling load of the system is relatively high in July and August. During the period of relatively low cooling load, only one big chiller or one small chiller needs to be turned on. During the period of relatively large cooling load, both the big chiller and the small chiller need to be turned on at the same time, or even all chillers at the same time. The result of the sequence control in Fig. 8 matches the cooling load data in Fig. 4, which shows the effectiveness of the control and the rationality of the data. b) Cooling load distribution analysis. Fig. 9 shows the relationship between COP of chillers and PLR, where the abscissa represents the PLR of chillers, and the ordinate represents the chiller COP under the PLR. Figs. 10 and 11 show the PLR density distributions of the big chiller 1# and small chiller 3# in the first, third, and sixth year, where the abscissa represents the PLR of chillers, and the ordinate represents the probability density of PLR. Fig. 12 shows the density distribution of the ratio selected in the first, third, and sixth years of the MA-CWSC method and DQN control method, where the abscissa represents the selected action (the ratio value), and the ordinate is the probability density corresponding to the action. Actually, the optimal energy-saving policy is determined by the characteristics of chillers. Fig. 9 shows that the COP of the small chiller is the largest when the PLR is 30%, and then gradually becomes smaller as the PLR increases. The COP of the big chiller increases with the increase of the PLR and remains basically constant after the PLR reaches 70%. Based on the above characteristics, the optimal policy should be to distribute a larger amount of cooling load to the big chiller, and a little amount of cooling load to the small chiller, so that the COP of all chillers is maximized. Figs. 10 and 11 show that: 1) The model-based control method maintains the PLR of the big chiller at about 70%, and the PLR of the small chiller at about 55%. 2) The Baseline control method distributes the cooling load according to the nominal chilled water flow of chillers, which keeps the PLR of the big chiller at about 65% and the PLR of the small chiller at about 70%. 3) MA-CWSC method has a lot of exploration in the first year, resulting in relatively discrete PLR. In the 3rd year, the PLR of big chillers is concentrated around 0.8, and in the 10th year, it has stabilized at 0.75, which is basically close to the model-based control. Compared with the model-based control method, the MA-CWSC method distributes more cooling load to big chillers and less cooling load to the small chiller, which is determined by the agent that chooses the ratio. 4) From Figs. 10 to 12, it can be seen that, the action distribution of the DQN control method is basically similar to the MA-CWSC method in the first and third years. In the sixth year, the action distribution of the MA-CWSC method is close to the model-based control method, while the action distribution of the DQN control method varies a lot. This also shows that the DQN control method converges slower than the MA-CWSC method because the action space of the DQN control method is much larger than that of the MA-CWSC method. The optimal ratio selected by the model-based control method is concentrated at around 0.67, while the ratio determined by the MA-CWSC method is around 0.7 (Fig. 12). This also results in a slightly larger PLR of a big chiller with the MA-CWSC method than with the model-based control method. In essence, this is the one of main reasons that the energy saving effect with the MA-CWSC method cannot reach that with the model-based control method. c) Performance analysis of cooling tower and cooling water pump. Fig. 15 shows the relationship between the power and frequency of the cooling water pump and cooling tower, where the abscissa is the frequency, and the ordinate is the power corresponding to the frequency (Eq.19, a, b, and c are obtained by regression method from the data). Fig. 14 shows the density distribution of cooling tower frequency and cooling water pump frequency selected with the MA-CWSC method and model-based control method in the first, third and sixth year, where the abscissa represents the water pump frequency, and the ordinate represents the cooling tower fan frequency. Fig. 13 shows that the energy consumption of the cooling water pump and the cooling tower varies with increasing frequency. The higher the frequency of the cooling pump is, the faster the power of the cooling pump increases. This also explains that the total energy consumption of the cooling water pump is higher than that of the cooling tower, and the energy saving range of the cooling water pump is larger than that of the cooling tower (Appendix F). According to the equipment selection given in Table 1 and the characteristics of cooling towers and cooling water pumps in Fig. 14, the optimal cooling tower frequency and cooling pump frequency with the model-based control method are mainly distributed near (30 Hz, 30 Hz). From Fig. 14, we can find that, compared with the baseline control method ( f tower = 50 H z , f pump = 50 H z ), the MA-CWSC method selects a larger distribution range in the first year. The reason is that the MA-CWSC method has a lot of exploration in the early stage. However, when the MA-CWSC method learns to the 3rd year, the selection of the frequency has been able to approach the optimal frequency very well. By the 6th year, it is basically the same as the optimal frequency given by the model-based method. d) System COP analysis. Fig. 15 gives the distribution of the system COP for the four control methods at years 1, 3, 6, and 10. The distribution of system COP for MA-CWSC-based and DQN control methods is between the baseline control method (5.0) and the model-based control method (5.7) and is increasing during the decade. In the first 3 years, the system COP for the DQN control method is equal to or even slightly higher than that for the MA-CWSC method. However, in years 4 to 10, the system COP for the MA-CWSC method is significantly superior to those for the DQN control method due to the parallel learning of all agents in MA-CWSC during this period. More importantly, in year 6, the COP distribution of the MA-CWSC method is already very close to that of the model-based method (also can refer to Fig. 7 or Fig. 16 ), which reflects the great potential of the MA-CWSC method. 7.4 Energy consumption analysis Fig. 16 shows the average annual energy saving rate (compared with the baseline control method) of the three control methods under five rounds of independent experiments. The abscissa represents the years and the ordinate represents the energy saving rate compared to the baseline control method. Figs. 17–19 (more details are provided in Appendix F) show the energy consumption of chillers, cooling water pumps, and cooling towers in 20 years. Fig. 16 shows that the annual energy saving rate of the MA-CWSC method and the DQN control method has gradually increased from 7.5% to 11.1% in 20 years, slightly inferior to the model-based control method (11.6%). Although DQN has better energy savings than MA-CWSC in the first three years, the actual energy savings improvement is relatively poor, and in the real deployment, it is difficult to make the end user accept the long time convergence with a good result, so actually, DQN is unpractical especially for our problem, but for some small scale problem, maybe DQN can handle it. In contrast, MA-CWSC only need one-third time, about 6 years, to achieve a relatively good performance, which is actually a big improvement about the convergence rate compared with DQN. Moreover, although the final energy saving rate of the DQN control method is better than that of the MA-CWSC method, this value is only about 0.2%, which we think is acceptable. Figs. 17–20 shows that the total energy consumption of cooling towers and cooling water pumps decreases continuously in 6 years. Although there are faint fluctuations in cooling tower energy consumption, the proportion of cooling tower energy consumption to total energy consumption is relatively small (about 15%), which means that the energy consumption of cooling towers has little impact on the total energy consumption of the system. Specifically, in Fig. 19, the MA-CWSC method makes the energy consumption of big chillers rise continuously until it is higher than that of the model-based control method, while the energy consumption of the small chiller decreases continuously until it is lower than that of the model-based control method. This is mainly due to the continuous optimization of load distribution with the MA-CWSC method, which distributes more cooling load to big chillers and less cooling load to the small chiller (Figs. 10 and 13). Both the model-based control method and the MA-CWSC method have lower energy consumption than the baseline control method for both cooling towers and cooling water pumps. This results in both control methods being inferior to the baseline control method in terms of cooling water heat dissipation and results in greater energy consumption of chillers. This is reflected in Appendix F that the total energy consumption of chillers is instead greater for a better cooling load distribution. The total energy consumption of the system for the MA-CWSC method decreases year by year until it stabilizes at 809000KWH in the 11th year, slightly higher than that of the model-based control method, which also reflects the satisfactory performance of the MA-CWSC method. Importantly, based on the experimental results, the control method has now been deployed in a commercial building in Shanghai. 8 Conclusion and Future This paper proposes a model-free optimization control method based on MA-CWSC to optimize the control of HVAC systems in commercial buildings. This method does not need to establish an accurate HVAC system model during the actual deployment, and uses Multiple agents to control the load distribution rate, cooling tower fan frequency, and cooling water pump frequency separately. To verify the performance of the algorithms, a simulation case system based on the EnergyPlus standard equipment model, actual HAVC system parameters and relevant historical data was built to compare the control methods: baseline control method, model-based control method and DQN control method. The experimental results show that the MA-CWSC method can learn energy saving policy quickly, and has almost the same energy saving effect as the model-based control method in the 6th year. Moreover, the policy can be continuously optimized over time. Although the MA-CWSC method has achieved related good performance, it still has two limitations. The first one is the MA-CWSC method is based on the discrete action while the actual action may be continuous, so, the discretization of the continuous action will affect the performance of the method. The other is the construction of the optimal action in our paper, where each agent chooses an optimal sub-action and combine all sub actions to construct the final optimal action. But the problem is that, the combination of all optimal sub-actions does not mean the optimal action in the final phase, which also results in a slightly lower performance than the DQN method after the 17th year. The model-free control method based on MA-CWSC is not intended to completely replace the model-based control method, but to provide an alternative optimal control scheme when an accurate system performance model cannot be established in the absence of data or many sensors cannot be deployed. Future studies can focus on the following three aspects: (1) Refine the action space, or choose a reinforcement learning algorithm that deals with continuous action space problems to improve the load distribution effect. (2) Establish a reasonable communication mechanism between agents to improve learning efficiency. (3) The controller based on reinforcement learning can still maintain a good control effect when the performance of the equipment changes. However, how to update the control policy faster and more reasonable is our next research direction. coredata.dc:description: In HVAC control problems, model-based optimal control methods have been extensively studied and verified by many researchers, but they highly depend on the accuracy of the model, a large amount of historical data, and the deployment of different sensors. With respect to the above problems, this paper proposed a Multi-Agent deep reinforcement learning method for the building Cooling Water System Control (MA-CWSC) to optimize the load distribution, cooling tower fan frequency, and cooling water pump frequency of different types of chillers, which provide a model-free and online learning mechanism. In the learning process, unlike the traditional reinforcement learning methods, the proposed control method uses five agents to control different controllable parts by parallel learning, which can greatly reduce the action space and speed up the convergence rate. In order to verify the effectiveness of the propose-d control method, based on the actual building cooling water system parameters and related historical data, we construct an experimental building cooling water system model, and moreover, we test the MA-CWSC method, model-based control method (optimal control method), baseline method, and single-agent deep reinforcement learning (deep Q-network). The experimental results show that the energy saving performance of the proposed MA-CWSC method is significantly better than the rule-based control method (11.1% improvement), and is very close to that of the model-based control method (only 0.5% difference). In addition, the MA-CWSC method has a faster learning rate compared to the deep Q-network (DQN) control method.
coredata.dc:title: Optimal control method of HVAC based on multi-agent deep reinforcement learning
